awd_titl_txt: Neural Mechanisms of Semantic and Episodic Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
The human episodic memory system supports the ability to remember one's past experience, while the semantic memory system supports memory for one's general knowledge about the world and the people, places, and things within it. These systems are interrelated: The semantic memory system allows one to construct representations of the features and details making up an experience, and the episodic memory system binds these semantic representations to a unique spatiotemporal context. Despite the critical importance of these systems, there are major gaps in our knowledge regarding the nature of the neural and cognitive mechanisms that allow us to flexibly access, manipulate, and retrieve episodic and semantic memories.  With funding from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Sean Polyn of Vanderbilt University is developing the Control of Semantic and Episodic Memory (CSEM) model, a novel theory designed to explain the how the brain mediates episodic and semantic memory search and retrieval.  This project will involve undergraduate students, graduate students, and research staff at every level: data analysis, theory development, and presentation of results to the broader scientific community.  The project's objectives will make key contributions to infrastructure for research and education, as the simulation software and the database of anonymized behavioral and neural data will be distributed to the broader scientific and academic community via the internet, along with a repository of behavioral and neural analysis tools.

The CSEM model is a computational model of human memory designed to test hypotheses regarding the specific mechanisms carried out by particular brain regions in the storage, retrieval, and flexible use of semantic and episodic memories.  The research team will use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to record blood-oxygen-level dependent (BOLD) activity as participants perform semantic and episodic memory tasks.  Multivariate pattern analysis, representational similarity analysis, and advanced statistical techniques will be used to characterize the representational structure and dynamics of neural activity, supporting the development of functional, mechanistic computational models of the cognitive system of participants as they perform the memory tasks.  The first study examines neural signals for evidence of an integrative contextual representation that allows information about recent experiences to persist in neural activity patterns.  The second study examines how the neural system constructs a retrieval cue that can be used to target particular sets of memories.  The third study examines how memories interfere with one another during retrieval, and the mechanisms used by the neural system to resolve this interference.  Data from these experiments will support the development of a unified theoretical framework to understand how general-purpose executive processes control the semantic and episodic memory systems to give rise to flexible, goal-directed behavior.

por.por_cntn:
In this NSF-funded research, Principal Investigator (PI) Dr Sean Polyn of Vanderbilt University and his research team developed a computational model of human memory search. To guide development of the model, the team carried out a series of experiments as healthy participants performed the free-recall memory search task. In this task participants study a series of items one at a time, and then report the items in whatever order they come to mind. Over the course of the award, 4 graduate students (1 who successfully defended her PhD during the award period), 10 undergraduate research assistants (3 doing Honors-level projects), and 1 post-bac research assistant were trained in experimental psychology and neuroscience research, including data science analysis, experimental design and responsible conduct of behavioral experimentation, theory and the scientific literature, and presentation of scientific results to peers and the broader scientific community at Vanderbilt and internationally attended scientific conferences. 

In a peer-reviewed paper published in 2019, the research team collaborated with Prof. M. Duff (Vanderbilt University), to examine semantic memory search in patients with hippocampal damage and anterograde amnesia. A semantic analysis of patient responses in a feature generation task (describing common objects) showed that their successive responses were less related to one another than healthy comparison patients. This work extends our understanding of hippocampal function, showing that hippocampal damage involves more than an episodic memory deficit. Another peer-reviewed paper from 2019, in collaboration with Prof. L. Fazio (Vanderbilt University) examined the cognitive mechanisms involved in retrieval practice. After studying a set of materials, a practice period is much more effective at bolstering learning if it involves retrieval practice than if it simply involves restudying the material. A popular account proposes that this benefit is related to the successful retrieval of the episodic context of the study event. Here, the research team demonstrated that key features of the original study event are not strengthened after performing retrieval practice, raising questions about the generality of the episodic context account. They propose instead that the practice-related enhancement is more related to the successful reactivation of the item itself, rather than its context.

The team created a modeling framework to construct and compare different versions of the project's central computational model, which accounts for behavioral performance and neural signals in free recall. The model proposes the memory system retrieves multiple aspects of items' semantic meaning when they are studied (i.e., knowledge about the features and characteristics of the items), and provides insight into how these semantic components are used by the memory system. These distinct semantic components explain the dynamics of category-specific neural activity during both study and recall. The PI has made the modeling code freely available to the scientific community on the popular code-sharing site GitHub, and a forthcoming book chapter provides a tutorial overview of how the code works to facilitate engagement by students and others. The scientific impact of this modeling work will continue to grow as the PI and his team use this resource in upcoming publications, which will acknowledge this NSF-supported project. 

In an experiment examining free recall of categorized materials (behavioral N=96, functional MRI N=27), participants performed an effortful distraction task in the intervals between the presentation of study items. The intensity of this distraction task was manipulated, demonstrating that with a more effortful task, neural signals indicating category and semantic identity were disrupted. This revealed a dissociation between temporal lobe regions, where semantic activity was not disrupted by the distraction task, and parietal lobe, where semantic activity was disrupted. This work extends theories regarding the contribution of these regions to memory-related behavior. This work has been presented to the scientific community at several recent conferences, and the scientific impact will grow as this work is described in upcoming publications describing the empirical findings and fitting the computational model to these data. These publications will acknowledge NSF support from this project. 

In 6 behavioral free-recall experiments, the research team examined a behavioral phenomenon known as the contiguity effect. This effect demonstrates the importance of the temporal structure of an experience (that is, the specific sequence of events within an episode) for later memory for that experience. Prior work has suggested that the contiguity effect is nearly ubiquitous in free recall performance, and computational theories have focused on the mechanisms that give rise to the effect. In this work, the research team demonstrates that it is possible to have successful recall performance without an observable contiguity effect. The study demonstrates the experimental conditions necessary to observe, and abolish, this effect, which will inform cognitive theories of memory. Upcoming publications describing this work will acknowledge NSF support from this project. Once published, the data will be posted online and made freely available as an enduring resource.
